briefdescription.para: Option flag indicating ClustalW formatted files.
Option flag indicating Stockholm 1.0 formatted files.
Option flag indicating FASTA (Pearson) formatted files.
Option flag indicating MAF formatted files.
Option flag indicating most informative sequence (MIS) output.

detaileddescription.para: The default reference sequence output for an alignment is simply a consensus sequence. This flag allows to write the most informative equence (MIS) instead.

briefdescription.para: Option flag indicating the set of default file formats.
Option flag to disable validation of the alignment.
Return flag of vrna_file_msa_detect_format() to indicate unknown or malformatted alignment.
Option flag indicating to append data to a multiple sequence alignment file rather than overwriting it.
Option flag to suppress unnecessary spam messages on stderr
Option flag to completely silence any warnings on stderr

memberdef.argsstring: (const char *filename, char ***names, char ***aln, char **id, char **structure, unsigned int options)
memberdef.name: vrna_file_msa_read

briefdescription.para: Read a multiple sequence alignment from file.

detaileddescription.para: This function reads the (first) multiple sequence alignment from an input file. The read alignment is split into the sequence id/name part and the actual sequence information and stored in memory as arrays of ids/names and sequences. If the alignment file format allows for additional information, such as an ID of the entire alignment or consensus structure information, this data is retrieved as well and made available. The options parameter allows to specify the set of alignment file formats that should be used to retrieve the data. If 0 is passed as option, the list of alignment file formats defaults to VRNA_FILE_FORMAT_MSA_DEFAULT.

Currently, the list of parsable multiple sequence alignment file formats consists of:
msa-formats-clustal
msa-formats-stockholm
msa-formats-fasta
msa-formats-maf
After successfully reading an alignment, this function performs a validation of the data that includes uniqueness of the sequence identifiers, and equal sequence lengths. This check can be deactivated by passing VRNA_FILE_FORMAT_MSA_NOCHECK in the options parameter. It is the users responsibility to free any memory occupied by the output arguments names, aln, id, and structure after calling this function. The function automatically sets the latter two arguments to NULL in case no corresponding data could be retrieved from the input alignment.
vrna_file_msa_read_record(), VRNA_FILE_FORMAT_MSA_CLUSTAL, VRNA_FILE_FORMAT_MSA_STOCKHOLM, VRNA_FILE_FORMAT_MSA_FASTA, VRNA_FILE_FORMAT_MSA_MAF, VRNA_FILE_FORMAT_MSA_DEFAULT, VRNA_FILE_FORMAT_MSA_NOCHECK
filename
The name of input file that contains the alignment
names
An address to the pointer where sequence identifiers should be written to
aln
An address to the pointer where aligned sequences should be written to
id
An address to the pointer where the alignment ID should be written to (Maybe NULL)
structure
An address to the pointer where consensus structure information should be written to (Maybe NULL)
options
Options to manipulate the behavior of this function
The number of sequences in the alignment, or -1 if no alignment record could be found
SWIG Wrapper Notes
In the target scripting language, only the first and last argument, filename and options, are passed to the corresponding function. The other arguments, which serve as output in the C-library, are available as additional return values. This function exists as an overloaded version where the options parameter may be omitted! In that case, the options parameter defaults to VRNA_FILE_FORMAT_MSA_STOCKHOLM. See, e.g. embed:rst:inline :py:func:`RNA.file_msa_read()` in the :doc:`/api_python` and embed:rst:inline :ref:`examples/python:parsing alignments` in the Python examples.

memberdef.argsstring: (FILE *fp, char ***names, char ***aln, char **id, char **structure, unsigned int options)
memberdef.name: vrna_file_msa_read_record

briefdescription.para: Read a multiple sequence alignment from file handle.

detaileddescription.para: Similar to vrna_file_msa_read(), this function reads a multiple sequence alignment from an input file handle. Since using a file handle, this function is not limited to the first alignment record, but allows for looping over all alignments within the input.

The read alignment is split into the sequence id/name part and the actual sequence information and stored in memory as arrays of ids/names and sequences. If the alignment file format allows for additional information, such as an ID of the entire alignment or consensus structure information, this data is retrieved as well and made available. The options parameter allows to specify the alignment file format used to retrieve the data. A single format must be specified here, see vrna_file_msa_detect_format() for helping to determine the correct MSA file format.

Currently, the list of parsable multiple sequence alignment file formats consists of:
msa-formats-clustal
msa-formats-stockholm
msa-formats-fasta
msa-formats-maf
After successfully reading an alignment, this function performs a validation of the data that includes uniqueness of the sequence identifiers, and equal sequence lengths. This check can be deactivated by passing VRNA_FILE_FORMAT_MSA_NOCHECK in the options parameter. It is the users responsibility to free any memory occupied by the output arguments names, aln, id, and structure after calling this function. The function automatically sets the latter two arguments to NULL in case no corresponding data could be retrieved from the input alignment.
vrna_file_msa_read(), vrna_file_msa_detect_format(), VRNA_FILE_FORMAT_MSA_CLUSTAL, VRNA_FILE_FORMAT_MSA_STOCKHOLM, VRNA_FILE_FORMAT_MSA_FASTA, VRNA_FILE_FORMAT_MSA_MAF, VRNA_FILE_FORMAT_MSA_DEFAULT, VRNA_FILE_FORMAT_MSA_NOCHECK
fp
The file pointer the data will be retrieved from
names
An address to the pointer where sequence identifiers should be written to
aln
An address to the pointer where aligned sequences should be written to
id
An address to the pointer where the alignment ID should be written to (Maybe NULL)
structure
An address to the pointer where consensus structure information should be written to (Maybe NULL)
options
Options to manipulate the behavior of this function
The number of sequences in the alignment, or -1 if no alignment record could be found
SWIG Wrapper Notes
In the target scripting language, only the first and last argument, fp and options, are passed to the corresponding function. The other arguments, which serve as output in the C-library, are available as additional return values. This function exists as an overloaded version where the options parameter may be omitted! In that case, the options parameter defaults to VRNA_FILE_FORMAT_MSA_STOCKHOLM. See, e.g. embed:rst:inline :py:func:`RNA.file_msa_read_record()` in the :doc:`/api_python` and embed:rst:inline :ref:`examples/python:parsing alignments` in the Python examples.

briefdescription.para: Detect the format of a multiple sequence alignment file.

detaileddescription.para: This function attempts to determine the format of a file that supposedly contains a multiple sequence alignment (MSA). This is useful in cases where a MSA file contains more than a single record and therefore vrna_file_msa_read() can not be applied, since it only retrieves the first. Here, one can try to guess the correct file format using this function and then loop over the file, record by record using one of the low-level record retrieval functions for the corresponding MSA file format.

simplesect.para: This function parses the entire first record within the specified file. As a result, it returns VRNA_FILE_FORMAT_MSA_UNKNOWN not only if it can't detect the file's format, but also in cases where the file doesn't contain sequences!

parameterdescription.para: The name of input file that contains the alignment
Options to manipulate the behavior of this function

simplesect.para: The MSA file format, or VRNA_FILE_FORMAT_MSA_UNKNOWN

parblock.para: This function exists as an overloaded version where the options parameter may be omitted! In that case, the options parameter defaults to VRNA_FILE_FORMAT_MSA_DEFAULT. See, e.g. embed:rst:inline :py:func:`RNA.file_msa_detect_format()` in the :doc:`/api_python` .

memberdef.argsstring: (const char *filename, const char **names, const char **aln, const char *id, const char *structure, const char *source, unsigned int options)
memberdef.name: vrna_file_msa_write

simplesect.para: Currently, we only support msa-formats-stockholm output

parameterdescription.para: The array of sequence names / identifies
An optional ID for the alignment
A string describing the source of the alignment
Options to manipulate the behavior of this function

simplesect.para: Non-null upon successfully writing the alignment to file

parblock.para: In the target scripting language, this function exists as a set of overloaded versions, where the last four parameters may be omitted. If the options parameter is missing the options default to (VRNA_FILE_FORMAT_MSA_STOCKHOLM | VRNA_FILE_FORMAT_MSA_APPEND). See, e.g. embed:rst:inline :py:func:`RNA.file_msa_write()` in the :doc:`/api_python` .

briefdescription.para: Functions dealing with file formats for Multiple Sequence Alignments (MSA)
